comments:
I have a .rptdesign file that worked under 1.0.1.  When I try to run ENGINE.openReportDesign( <path> ); as before, I get an error:

java.lang.NullPointerException
at org.eclipse.birt.report.engine.api.ReportEngine.openReportDesign(ReportEngine.java:219)
at com.labcorp.cels.pla.domain.reporting.Report.generate(Report.java:75)
at com.labcorp.cels.pla.domain.organization.LabCorp.main(LabCorp.java:151)

The file for the path is the same as before, the file is there, and using an XML editor it appears to be well-formed.

Created an attachment (id=33380)
The file that will not open in BIRT 2.0RC2

XML design file
Althrough I don't have the imported classes and the final report is not created, I open the report design sucessfully in my build.

(In reply to comment #2)
> Althrough I don't have the imported classes and the final report is not
> created, I open the report design sucessfully in my build.
> 

Do you mean that you open it for design view in Eclipse?  If so, this is not where I have the problem - I can open it for viewing in IDE also.

The problem is opening it for generation-> ENGINE.openReportDesign( <path> );
If that is what you did successfully, then what do you recommend I do, since I get a NullPointerException??

I have upgraded to the 2.0.0 final and this still occurs.

I went into the ReportEngine.java source code to attempt to identify what is failing with a NullPointerException.  I believe it is during this line (the full method follows):

return helper.openReportDesign( designName );

Can someone from the BIRT team give me some idea what might be wrong?  I assume the "helper" is null, but I don't know why or how to fix it.

================== method source ===========
/**
 * opens a report design file and creates a report design runnable. From the
 * ReportRunnable object, embedded images and parameter definitions can be
 * retrieved. Constructing an engine task requires a report design runnable
 * object.
 *  * @param designName
 *            the full path of the report design file
 * @return a report design runnable object
 * @throws EngineException
 *             throwed when the input file does not exist, or the file is
 *             invalid
 */
public IReportRunnable openReportDesign( String designName )
throws EngineException
{
return helper.openReportDesign( designName );
}

Found out what the problem was.  The tables on the report were too wide.  Even if I said 100% or blank or anything else, they went over the right side.  Once I reduced the Master page margins so they fit, the NullPointerException went away.

This *is* a BIRT bug.

Found out what the problem was.  The tables on the report were too wide.  Even
if I said 100% or blank or anything else, they went over the right side.  Once
I reduced the Master page margins so they fit, the NullPointerException went
away.

This *is* a BIRT bug

I just ran this again in the debugger, and sure enough "helper = null".  I don't know what this means...am I supposed to set this up?

Someone please help with this!

(In reply to comment #7)
> I just ran this again in the debugger, and sure enough "helper = null".  I
> don't know what this means...am I supposed to set this up?

> Someone please help with this!
> 

Seems to be related to when it is generated relative to other reports.  If I run it by itself now (that I've fit it on the master page), it works fine. If I gen three reports in a row, with the one getting the NPE last, it fails every time.

I'm attaching the other two report designs as well as a jar for my supporting POJOs.  Run the Employee Efficiency report last.

Sorry about the missing package

The finalize() function in Report is not right. You shouldn't use engine.destroy() there, because you can't know when it will run. You should use engine.detroy() just when you don't need using engine object any more.

(In reply to comment #21)
> The finalize() function in Report is not right. You shouldn't use
> engine.destroy() there, because you can't know when it will run. You should use
> engine.detroy() just when you don't need using engine object any more.
>
